intro: Crataegus brevispina var. microphylla, commonly known as the small-fruited hawthorn, is a deciduous shrub or small tree native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its small, thornless stems and oval-shaped leaves that are typically 2–4 cm in length. The plant produces white to pink flowers in spring, followed by small, red berries in the fall. Its leaves are often covered with fine hairs, and the plant is adapted to a variety of soil types, including sandy and clay soils. It is often found in woodland edges and open areas, contributing to local biodiversity.
